turns.message: Hey, no problem at all—I totally get it. Grad apps are stressful! For public speaking, try practicing in smaller settings first, like study groups, to build confidence. For grad school, start by reaching out to professors whose work interests you; they can offer guidance and maybe even become mentors. You've got this—just take it one step at a time.

turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's totally normal to feel nervous about networking. Start small—practice introducing yourself to one new person in class or online. Prepare a short "elevator pitch" about your interests in computer science. Remember, many people feel the same way, and it gets easier with practice. You've got this!

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common fear! If you freeze, take a breath and say, "That's a great question, let me think for a moment." It's okay not to have all the answers—being honest shows authenticity. You can always follow up later via email. Practice your pitch with a friend to build confidence. You're more capable than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know I should practice, but the thought of even doing a mock interview makes my stomach hurt. What if I can't think of anything to say after I take that breath?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a completely valid feeling. Let's make it less intimidating: practice just the first 30 seconds of your pitch in front of a mirror. If your mind goes blank, have a simple, honest line ready like, "I'm a bit nervous, but I'm really passionate about this field." It humanizes you and gives you a moment to reset. Small, low-pressure steps build confidence.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart thing to prepare for. Write your "reset line" on a small notecard and keep it in your pocket. Just knowing it's there can be a huge relief. You can also practice with the camera off in a virtual setting first. The goal isn't perfection—it's progress. You're building a skill, and it's okay to have moments that feel awkward.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great point. The card is just a safety net, not a script. Try practicing your answer to one common question, then immediately talk about something you genuinely love in your field. This switch can help you sound more natural and passionate, which interviewers really respond to. You've got this.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a perfect plan. To make the passion part feel natural, don't describe it—tell a short story. Instead of "I'm passionate," say, "I got hooked when I built my first simple app and saw it work." A real, small moment is always authentic and memorable. You can do this.
